awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Scrutable and Explainable Information Retrieval with Model Intrinsic and Agnostic Approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
Information Retrieval (IR) systems are important for people for information access. For example, intelligent search engines are widely used in Web-based services such as web search, product search, and job search. Recently, sophisticated data and complicated black-box models have made modern IR systems less transparent to users. However, as more and more people rely on IR systems to guide their daily life and decision making, there has been growing needs of explainable search results, both for technical communities and the general public, so that they understand why certain search results are provided. Meanwhile, governmental agencies are demanding IR systems to provide not only high-quality results, but also reasonable justifications, so as to enhance the trustworthiness of the systems. This project focuses on developing algorithms and frameworks to improve the scrutability, explainability, and transparency of modern IR systems. It will inspire large-scale academic-industry collaboration, which benefits billions of users by facilitating the development of reliable and explainable information access services. 

This project will develop general and reusable frameworks for scrutable and explainable IR. Research in this project will be performed on two directions. The first direction aims at new retrieval models for model-intrinsic explanation. This includes developing transparent inference process and decision boundaries for retrieval actions, scrutable functions that support result exploration with user feedback, and traceable information flow to distinguish the contribution of model inputs. The second direction aims at building analytical and simulative framework for model-agnostic explanation. This includes post-hoc explanation systems with external knowledge, and a simulation framework over black-box retrieval models with explainable outputs. Besides model-intrinsic and model-agnostic approaches, this project will also investigate crowd-sourcing tasks and systematic metrics to compare the effectiveness of intrinsic and agnostic explanations. The research outcomes will include multiple public benchmark datasets and evaluation platforms for explainable IR, which will contribute to the research community for sustainable and reproducible future studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to improve information retrieval (IR) systems along three dimensions: studying methods to help users understand them better, designing explanation systems for them, and developing new evaluations for them.
We compared model-agnostic (post hoc) and model-intrinsic explanations in the context of e-commerce search. We found that both types of explanations have value. While the former better engage users toward making their purchase, the latter may be more faithful and reliable. We conducted experiments on explaining search with user-generated content like text reviews and found this to be an effective strategy.
An important part of training conversational search systems involves simulating user responses. We conducted an in-depth investigation of the task of simulating user responses for conversational search. We demonstrated that advanced natural language processing (NLP) models can be effective at this task.  Furthermore, our work revealed systematic challenges in using standard datasets for evaluating user simulators. We showed that by introducing a latent variable which captures the type of the clarifying question to ask, we can substantially outperform even the largest language models with a much smaller specialized model. Finally, we also showed that the cooperativeness of users is an important aspect of the user simulation task; this aspect merits further investigation.
We used the framework of imitation learning for developing conversational search capabilities. Our work showed that a trained conversation policy can help guide conversational retrieval models to balance conversational search quality and efficiency. We also designed a new multi-turn, multi-response metric that evaluates entire multi-turn conversational search sessions comprehensively, taking into account both search result quality and search efficiency.
Given the prevalence of large language models in search, we studied their robustness to the order in which examples are presented to them. We developed simple, yet effective, heuristics for example ordering to help make even small models more robust. Finally, with an eye towards efficiency, we benchmarked the recently proposed family of state-space models for information retrieval tasks. Our evaluations showed that these models hold promise in terms of both effectiveness and efficiency.
